awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Water partitioning between trees, soils, and streams following forest disturbance
awd_abstract_narration:
Over half of the freshwater supply in the contiguous United States originates in forested watersheds. It is thus critical that forested headwater catchments are properly managed to ensure clean and ample water supplies for aquatic ecosystems and downstream communities. Research on forested experimental watersheds has established that reducing forest cover generally increases water yield and that afforestation decreases water yield. However, there is still not agreement on the magnitude and persistence of changes in streamflow, particularly during periods of the highest and lowest streamflow. This is because the connection between forest harvesting, or other forest disturbances, and streamflow is essentially a "black box", whereby the mechanisms influencing streamflow are not understood. This research will broaden our process-based understanding of forest hydrology by investigating how contemporary forest management affects water movement and storage in a well-studied coastal California watershed. Results of this research will provide evidence to motivate new forest management in coastal watersheds and lead to better foundational knowledge of the linkages between vegetation and water supply. These results will be generated in conjunction with the USDA Forest Service and the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection, which will use the results to update California's Forest Practice Rules. 

It is increasingly critical to improve our quantitative understanding of how forest disturbances affect the storage and release of water through catchments. However, it is not yet understood how disturbances impact water compartmentalization at time scales other than the annual water balance. This is because the mechanisms by which streamflow increases can only be inferred in paired watershed studies, which have been the most popular tool for quantifying hydrological effects of forest disturbance. A combined mass balance and dual water isotope approach offers the potential to critically improve our understanding of the effects of disturbances on the processes and mechanisms that drive water storage and release. Here, it is hypothesized that the ecohydrological response of a forested watershed is proportional to the severity of disturbance. Using different intensities of forest harvesting (0%, 35%, 55%, and 75% removal of pre-treatment vegetation) as a mechanism for studying forest disturbances, the following research questions will be addressed: How do increasing levels of disturbance affect the water budget at different hillslope positions? How does forest disturbance affect the separation of water between soils, groundwater, streams, and trees? To answer these questions, this study takes a novel approach to connect the processes by which forest disturbance affects water budgets, subsurface water movement, and plant water use by combining a mass balance analysis and dual water isotopes. All components of the water budget (i.e., streamflow, soil moisture, groundwater, evapotranspiration, and fog) will be monitored and coupled with dual stable isotopes (2H and 18O). This study also addresses critical calls for field-based hydrologic research to inform hydrologic models to answer key questions about disturbance impacts on water resources.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In our project, we investigated the effects of forest disturbance on the water budget, subsurface water movement, and plant water use in the Caspar Creek Experimental Watersheds on the Jackson Demonstration State Forest, in northern California. The region is characterized by a Mediterranean climate with dry summers and cool, wet winters. Study sites are dominated by coast redwood (Sequoia sempervirens) and Douglas-fir (Pseudotsuga menziesii) forests that were originally logged prior to the turn of the century and again in the early 1970s and 2018. We established replicated transects in four catchments that each included plots at five hillslope positions—riparian, toeslope, sideslope, shoulder, and ridge (20 sample plots). At each plot we periodically collected water samples from May 2016 to present (~23 discrete sampling events), to quantify dual isotopes (δ2H, δ18O) for precipitation, soil water (5–100 cm), shallow groundwater, streams, and trees. Our objectives were to determine the stable isotope composition of soil water, groundwater, streams, and trees. Longer-term we will investigate questions about how varying levels of forest disturbance (0, 35, 55, and 75% harvesting of pre-treatment vegetation) influence the stable isotope composition and partitioning of water between the various pools. Across all time periods of the pre-disturbance monitoring, the mean isotopic composition of streams (δ18O = -6.1‰, δ2H = -34.8‰) strongly reflected groundwater (δ18O = -6.2‰, δ2H = -35.5‰). At all plots, the soil-water isotope composition became more negative with depth, from an average δ18O = -2.4‰ and δ2H = -27.9‰ at 5 cm to a δ18O = -3.7‰ and δ2H = -41.9‰ at 100 cm. This general pattern is consistent with the rainout effects observed in other forested Mediterranean climates; this pattern appeared to strengthen during the summer dry period, also reflecting increasing evaporative loss from the upper soil layers. Interestingly, xylem water isotope composition (that averaged δ18O = -6.7‰, δ2H = -49.8‰) did not overlap with any other sampled pools of water (i.e., precipitation, soil, groundwater, bedrock water, fog), especially during summer. This implies that the trees are accessing or using a, yet unmeasured, source of water for transpiration.

 

The project is contributing to the field of hydrological sciences by improving our understanding of the impact of increasing levels of forest disturbance on subsurface water movement, catchment water storage, and plant water use in a coast redwood forest. Our study remains the first of its kind to investigate how watershed ecohydrological processes are altered by increasing levels of forest disturbance. These results can be used as a framework for understanding past and future results related to forest ecohydrology and disturbance hydrology. Future insights from combining our stable water isotope data with the water balance approach offer great potential to improve understanding of the compartmentalization of water and for improving hydrologic models. Moreover, with rapidly shifting disturbance regimes it is increasingly critical to improve our quantitative understanding and ability to model and predict how disturbances affect the spatial and temporal compartmentalization of parts of the terrestrial water cycle. Our results will also be of importance to hydrologic, ecologic, and biogeochemical watershed modelers who can further refine their models based upon our findings. Our results may also provide ideas and insights to individuals studying other disturbances such as pest and disease outbreak, droughts, and wildfire to see if different disturbances affect ecohydrologic processes in a fashion similar to harvesting.
